head.title: Anisotropic Swelling Governed by Orientation-Dependent Interfacial Na Diffusion in Single-Crystalline Sb | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Anisotropic Swelling Governed by Orientation-Dependent Interfacial Na Diffusion in Single-Crystalline Sb

The anisotropic volume expansion of anode materials produces locally inhomogeneous residual stresses, which frequently induce fracture of the anode materials and reduce battery capacity and cycle life. Much of our understanding of the anisotropic swelling behavior of anode materials is based on electron microscopy and macroscopic structural analysis techniques, which are insufficient to elucidate the atomistic origin of the anisotropic swelling behavior. In this study, we perform in situ sodiation experiments with single-crystalline Sb anodes followed by atomic simulations to determine the diffusion kinetics governing the sodiation of Sb and its associated swelling behavior. In situ sodiation experiments demonstrate that the rate of diffusion of Na into single-crystalline Sb anodes differs by more than a factor of 2 depending on the orientation of the Sb crystal, causing the crystal to swell anisotropically. This observed anisotropic diffusion is explained here by determining the orientation-dependent diffusion kinetics, while the associated structural origins are clarified by studying the interfacial Na diffusion in the atomically thin layer preceding the advancing interface.

div.span: Supporting Info (5)
SUBJECTS:

div.p: The anisotropic volume expansion of anode materials produces locally inhomogeneous residual stresses, which frequently induce fracture of the anode materials and reduce battery capacity and cycle life. Much of our understanding of the anisotropic swelling behavior of anode materials is based on electron microscopy and macroscopic structural analysis techniques, which are insufficient to elucidate the atomistic origin of the anisotropic swelling behavior. In this study, we perform in situ sodiation experiments with single-crystalline Sb anodes followed by atomic simulations to determine the diffusion kinetics governing the sodiation of Sb and its associated swelling behavior. In situ sodiation experiments demonstrate that the rate of diffusion of Na into single-crystalline Sb anodes differs by more than a factor of 2 depending on the orientation of the Sb crystal, causing the crystal to swell anisotropically. This observed anisotropic diffusion is explained here by determining the orientation-dependent diffusion kinetics, while the associated structural origins are clarified by studying the interfacial Na diffusion in the atomically thin layer preceding the advancing interface.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Na is abundant and has a relatively low redox potential, making it an attractive economical alternative to Li for Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Moreover, when used with group IVA and VA elements, such as Sn, Pb, Sb, and P, Na ions (Na
+
) can diffuse to these anode materials via an alloying mechanism, so that Na-ion batteries (NIBs) exhibit large energy capacities. Although NIBs are economical with large theoretical capacities, Na insertion into the anode materials is always accompanied by a large volumetric expansion,
(1−3)
which induces local residual stresses and subsequent frequent fracture of the anode materials, degrading the battery capacity and cycle life.
(4)

Various techniques such as doping,
(5,6)
coating,
(7)
and structural design
(3,8−11)
have been developed to prevent anode fracture. Of these, the use of nanostructured anodes is probably the most widely explored method for relieving residual stresses induced by Na insertion (also termed “sodiation”) and therefore mitigating pulverization of the anode materials. For example, Sn nanowires can expand by up to ∼420% by volume without crack induction even after full Na insertion.
(12)
However, this rule has many exceptions; P nanowires, for instance, even with similar morphology and volume expansion (∼400%), undergo pulverization with consequent serious capacity loss.
(13)
The different sodiation behaviors displayed by Na–Sn and Na–P systems suggest that, as well as the size and morphology of the anode material, the material itself is an important factor affecting the cracking behavior of sodiated materials.

The crack formation and consequent pulverization of the anode material is attributed to uneven/anisotropic swelling originating from differing diffusion kinetics of carrier ions.
(14−16)
Although the diffusion kinetics of carrier ions and associated swelling behavior of the anode material are normally orientation-dependent,
(13,14,17)
anisotropic swelling behaviors are also affected by the bond energy of the anode material.
(12,18)
Generally, anode materials with strong interatomic bonds (e.g., P) are prone to anisotropic swelling,
(13,14)
whereas those with weak bonds (e.g., Sn) normally exhibit isotropic swelling (
Figure
1
). Recent atomic simulations indicated that when carrier ions diffuse to an anode material with weak bonds, diffusion proceeds by amorphization of the unreacted anode material preceding the advancing interface.
(12,18)
This amorphization behavior weakens the orientation effect on the diffusion rate, rendering charge carriers to diffuse isotropically to the anode material. However, the relation between the bond energy and swelling behavior remains incompletely established because of the limited numbers of sodiation experiments conducted on NIBs. Particularly, for some materials with bond energies from 200 to 350 kJ/mol, it remains unclear whether sodiation occurs anisotropically or isotropically (
Figure
1
). In this respect, Sb with a moderate bond energy of 300 kJ/mol is an ideal material for establishing the relation between the bond energy and sodiation behavior of anode materials.

div.p:
Figure 1. Degrees of anisotropic swelling determined for various group IVA and VA elements
(12−14,17,19)
with differing bond energies. The degree of anisotropic swelling (
R
) shown in the graph is defined as the ratio of the largest to smallest volume expansion obtained for various crystallographic orientations of the anode materials. The results relating to NIBs are denoted by circles, while those relating to LIBs are indicated by triangles, whereas the symbols with
R
< 1.1 and
R
> 1.2 are colored in blue and orange, respectively. The inverted triangles shown on the
x
-axis denote the bond energies of the atomic pairs reported in ref
(20)
.

div.div: In this work, we used single-crystalline Sb pillars with various orientations to conduct direct-contact in situ sodiation experiments to comprehend the fundamentals of the sodiation behavior of Sb crystals. The experiments revealed that the rate of diffusion of Na into Sb differs considerably depending on the Sb crystalline orientation, causing the Sb anode to swell anisotropically and promoting cracks. This observed anisotropic diffusion is explained here by analyzing the orientation-dependent diffusion kinetics, while the associated structural origins are elucidated by resolving the interfacial Na diffusion at the atomically thin layer preceding the advancing interface.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In order to understand the fundamentals of the sodiation behavior of Sb crystals, this paper address three issues and is organized as follows: (1) we first performed in situ observations of the sodiation behavior using a focused-ion beam (FIB) system to track the morphological changes of the Sb pillars during sodiation. (2) Using first-principles calculations on Na–Sb diffusion couples, we investigated the atomic-scale structural evolution occurring at regions near the reaction fronts of sodiated Sb pillars. (3) Finally, we evaluated the energy landscapes for the Na diffusion pathways along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions of the Sb crystal to interpret the underlying physics of the anisotropic sodiation of the Sb crystal.

To discuss the above-stated issues, appropriate terminologies (i.e., intercalation and alloying) are needed to describe the sodiation behaviors of the Sb anode. When a Na lump is attached to a Sb anode, Na
+
begin to penetrate into spaces between {0001} layers of the β-Sb phase. This “intercalation” process proceeds by widening the interspacing of {0001} layers of the β-Sb phase.
(21)
As sodiation continues, the layered structure of the β-Sb phase can no longer accommodate inflowing Na
+
by retaining its initial structure, and thus has to be transformed to another structure that can store more Na
+
. This phase transition associated with the continual supply of Na
+
causes the Sb anode to transform into Na
x
Sb compounds via “alloying” mechanism. However, in this study, when it is difficult to distinguish these two diffusion mechanisms, we also used the loose terminologies of “insertion” and “diffusion”.

div.h3: 2.1. In Situ Sodiation Behaviors of Single-Crystalline Sb
div.div:
In order to study how the anisotropic volume expansion affects the electrochemical performances of anodes, it is necessary to employ a technique that permits the exploration of the anisotropic diffusion behavior, while eliminating the effects of various unintended test parameters. However, most conventional electrochemical tests using full- or half-cell batteries are unable to resolve/extract accurately each factor from the collaborative effects of various test parameters (e.g., the effect of additives and binders and the presence of applied potential) determining the entire cell performance. Of various experimental techniques, direct-contact in situ diffusion experiments using a single-crystalline anode are probably the most effective means to explore the anisotropic swelling behaviors during lithiation/sodiation. When preparing single-crystalline Sb pillars, we selected the two crystallographic orientations, along which the diffusion rates are largely different; in general, the diffusion rate of charge carriers generally differs according to the crystallographic orientation of the anode material and is normally inversely proportional to the planar density of a crystal plane.
(22)
Thus, the diffusion behaviors of Na
+
in the Sb anode are investigated in directions with distinctively different planar densities. In crystalline Sb with hexagonal symmetry and a layered structure along the ⟨0001⟩ direction, the {0001} and {1100} planes exhibit the largest planar density difference. Thus, comparison of the Na diffusion rates along the ⟨0001⟩ and ⟨1–100⟩ directions of the Sb crystal enables the assessment of the sodiation rate dependency on the Sb crystallographic orientation. With this aim, we machined 1.5 μm diameter Sb pillars with their long axes parallel to ⟨0001⟩ and ⟨1–100⟩ (hereinafter referred to as Sb⟨0001⟩ and Sb⟨1–100⟩). Sodiation of the Sb pillars was then promoted by attaching a Na lump to the Sb pillars, as displayed in
Figure
2
a and summarized in detail in the
Methods
section.

div.p: Figure 2. (a) Secondary electron images showing the experimental setup of a FIB system used for the in situ sodiation experiment on Sb pillars. Morphological changes in the sodiated Sb pillars are recorded as a function of sodiation time with their long axis oriented along the (b) ⟨0001⟩ and (c) ⟨1–100⟩ directions.

div.div:
Figure
2
b,c shows a series of frames captured from movies recorded during in situ sodiation experiments, displaying continuous and spontaneous sodiation of Sb⟨0001⟩ and Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillars, respectively (
Movies S1
and
S2
in the Supporting Information). The Na diffusion rate differed considerably depending on the crystallographic orientation of the Sb pillars. Na diffusion along the ⟨0001⟩ direction of the Sb pillar was observed to be slow, as shown by the slowly moving phase boundary observed from the reaction front of the Sb pillar. Furthermore, the sodiation of the Sb⟨0001⟩ pillar causes only a minor volume expansion because the Na insertion is proceeded by sweeping over the pillar surface rather than full penetration into the pillar interior (as discussed in more detail in
Figure
3
). Considering the negligible changes in the morphology of the Sb pillar, this sodiation process is considered to follow the intercalation mechanism occurring along the radial direction of the pillar (i.e., ⟨1–100⟩ direction of the Sb crystal). Conversely, the Na diffusion rate was much faster in the ⟨1–100⟩ direction. Careful observation showed that diffusion in the ⟨1–100⟩ direction begins with Na alloying with the Sb pillar from the contact point, causing the pillar to swell by ∼80% (see the panel at
t
= 365 s in
Figure
2
c). Considering that the volume expansion of sodiated phases (i.e., Na
x
M, M = Si, Sn, Ge, Pb, etc.) is linearly proportional to the Na composition, that is,
x
of Na
x
M,
(1)
this initial swelling is considered to correspond to formation of an amorphous NaSb phase. As Na
+
continues to flow in the sodiated Sb anode, sodiation is accompanied by additional volume expansion and subsequent crack formation on the surface. During this stage, a continuous supply of Na
+
caused further expansion of the Sb pillar reaching ∼260%, indicating the formation of a Na
3
Sb phase. The presence of these intermediate NaSb and Na
3
Sb phases has also been reported in previous studies on the phase identification of the Na–Sb batteries.
(21,23)
However, this issue on the phase transition behaviors of the Na–Sb system is beyond the scope of the present study and thus will not be dealt further. When comparing the sodiation behaviors in the Sb⟨0001⟩ and Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillars, it is now concluded that the diffusion behavior of Na to the Sb crystal is anisotropic.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) Secondary electron image of a Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillar subjected to partial sodiation for 4000 s. (b) Magnified view of (a), showing crack propagation along the long axis of the pillar. Transverse cross-sectional views of (c,d) Sb⟨1–100⟩ and (e,f) Sb⟨0001⟩ pillars, showing the cross sections of the Sb pillars (c,e) before and (d,f) after partial sodiation. Note that the sodiated and unsodiated Sb are distinguished by gray and white contrasts, respectively.

div.div:
Anisotropic sodiation of the Sb pillars was confirmed by directly observing the morphology of the sodiated Sb pillars with their long axis aligned along ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩. Close examination of the side surface of the sodiated Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Sb⟨0001⟩ pillars reveals crack formation on the surface of the Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillar (
Figure
3
a,b, for the morphology of the sodiated Sb⟨0001⟩ pillar, see Figure S1 in the
Supporting Information
), indicating that anisotropic diffusion occurred in the radial/lateral direction of the sodiated Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillar. To directly observe anisotropic swelling of the sodiated Sb pillars, transverse cross sections of the sodiated Sb pillars were observed before and after sodiation. Comparing the cross sections of the sodiated Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillar indicates that the volume expansion differs significantly depending on the crystallographic direction, being largest along ⟨1120⟩ and smallest along ⟨0001⟩ (
Figure
3
c,d). Converting the measured volume expansion to the degree of anisotropic swelling (see
Figure
1
) gave a value of
R
≈ 2.0, which is comparable to that of the Na–P system. Conversely, unlike the Sb⟨1–100⟩ pillar, the cross section of Sb⟨0001⟩ reveals that only a small amount of Na
+
manages to diffuse through the side surface of the pillar (
Figure
3
e,f). With limited Na diffusion along ⟨0001⟩, this is a likely process because atoms can diffuse through the surface of a material at a much higher rate (by approximately 6 orders of magnitude) than through the lattice.
(24)
The above experimentally determined morphological changes in the Sb pillars suggest that Na diffusion into the Sb crystal is anisotropic.

A combination of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with finite element (FE) calculations has been the most popular technique for exploring anisotropic diffusion of different anode materials.
(15,25)
However, this method alone is insufficient for determining the structural origin of anisotropic sodiation behavior, as this originates primarily from reaction kinetics occurring at atomically thin regions/interfaces between pristine Sb and advancing sodiated phases (for the detailed description on this concept, refer to refs
(12)
and
(18)
), which cannot be resolved by combining TEM and FE calculations. Thus, to elucidate the fundamental physics underlying the anisotropic swelling behavior, a technique is required that can resolve the structural evolution near the advancing diffusion front on an atomic scale. Of all currently available techniques, first-principles calculations describe the most accurate interatomic interactions and therefore provide reliable structure–property relations for material systems. Using first-principles calculations as follows, we investigate the structural evolution at the phase boundaries of the sodiated Sb pillars by evaluating the reaction kinetics at Na–Sb diffusion couple interfaces.

div.h3: 2.2. Orientation-Dependent Sodiation Behavior and Associated Structural Evolution
div.div:
To evaluate the orientation dependency of the reaction kinetics and relate the results to the anisotropic diffusion behavior of Sb crystals, we prepared two different three-dimensional (3D) full-scale diffusion couples comprising Na and Sb (see insets in
Figure
4
a). This was attained by attaching a Na slab to the Sb slabs, aligning their respective orientations along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions to produce Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couples. The anisotropic sodiation behavior of the Sb crystal was then determined by calculating the Na diffusivity (
D
Na
) along the given directions using first-principles molecular dynamics (MD) (see
Methods
for details of the calculation procedures).

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Mean square displacement (⟨
r
2
⟩) of Na
+
calculated as a function of time for Na/Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Na/Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couples. The insets of (a) are full-scale calculation cells corresponding to Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couples. (b,c) Series of snapshots captured from the results of first-principles simulations (Supporting Information
Movies S3
and
S4
) show the structural evolution sequence at the interfaces of (b) Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ and (c) Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couples. Note that for (c), Na diffusion to the Sb⟨1–100⟩ crystal is accompanied by widened interspacing of the {0001} planes.

div.div:
The
D
Na
values of the Sb crystal were determined using the relation
,
(26)
where ⟨
r
2
⟩ is the mean square displacement of Na
+
during sodiation (see
Methods
for
D
Na
calculation).
Figure
4
a shows changes in the ⟨
r
2
⟩ values of Na
+
evaluated for Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couples at 500 K. The ⟨
r
2
⟩ values of the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couple appear to increase minimally during sodiation, indicating that Na diffusion along the ⟨0001⟩ direction of the Sb crystal is less probable. Na diffusion in the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple is relatively faster than that in the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couple, as revealed by the increase in ⟨
r
2
⟩ with time. When ⟨
r
2
⟩ was converted to diffusivity,
D
Na
was more than 20 times larger along ⟨1–100⟩ (9.2 × 10
–5
cm
2
·s
–1
) than along the ⟨0001⟩ direction (4.1 × 10
–6
cm
2
·s
–1
) of the Sb crystal.

To determine the structural origins of the diffusional anisotropy observed in the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions of the Sb crystal (
Figure
4
a), we further investigated the structural evolution at the interface of the diffusion couples (
Figure
4
b,c). For the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couple (
Figure
4
b), Sb{0001} planes with dense atomic packing appear to hinder Na diffusion, blocking Na penetration into the Sb crystal. However, the {1100} planes are characterized by relatively loose atomic packing (equivalent to weak interatomic bonding) and therefore provide open channels along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction (i.e., along the
x
-axis), enabling Na
+
to intercalate into the Sb crystal (
Figure
4
c). Another notable feature observed in
Figure
4
c is widening of the interspacing of the Sb{0001} layers; this increases by ∼0.3 Å as Na
+
begins to intercalate along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction of the Sb crystal (see the panel at 6 ps in
Figure
4
c). This widening of the {0001} interlayers of the Sb crystal was also experimentally observed by Tian et al.
(21)
Such structural evolution is considered to promote the alloying of Na with Sb, as revealed by the increased Na diffusion rates along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction of the Sb crystal; when examining the ⟨
r
2
⟩-
t
plot of the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple in
Figure
4
a, the slope of the plot drastically increases after the initial sodiation of ∼6 ps. This interpretation of the structural evolution at the interface explains why the Na diffusion into the Sb crystal is anisotropic and can be revealed by different energy for Na diffusion. This concept will be assessed quantitatively in the following by evaluating the energy landscapes for differing Na diffusion pathways that migrate along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions of the Sb crystal.

div.h3: 2.3. Diffusion Barrier Calculations for Sodiation of Sb
div.div:
It is known that diffusion occurs because of the presence of a concentration gradient of solute atoms (i.e., grad
C
) and proceeds by maintaining its macroscopic direction parallel to grad
C
(i.e., the
x
-axis in
Figure
4
). However, when viewed on an atomic scale, Na
+
cannot travel along a straight pathway parallel to the direction of grad
C
but migrate around the Sb lattice to avoid collision with Sb atoms, forcing Na
+
to break Sb–Sb bonds while following a tortuous path. The bond energies of Sb–Sb pairs differ according to the Sb crystallographic orientation as their respective bond distances are different. Such differences in the bond distances result in differing Na diffusion energy landscapes depending on the Sb crystal orientation. In this section, differences in the diffusion rates of Na
+
in the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couples were quantitatively analyzed by calculating the energy landscapes of the Na diffusion pathways along the ⟨0001⟩ and ⟨1–100⟩ directions.

Before calculating the energy landscapes of the Na diffusion pathways, we selected potential pathways for Na diffusion for each diffusion couple by connecting the interstitial Na sites in the Sb crystal such that Na diffusion proceeds along the ⟨0001⟩ and ⟨1–100⟩ directions (see
Figure
5
a–d and
Methods
for the detailed calculation procedures).
Figure
5
a,b shows Na diffusion pathways predicted for the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couple, showing a Na trajectory migrating along ⟨0001⟩ by occupying the interstitial Na sites, denoted by A, B, C, and D in the {0001} planes. These sites construct two different types of diffusion pathways for Na
+
: perpendicular (A → B, C → D) and parallel (B → C) to the {0001} planes of the Sb crystal. Repeated occurrence of these events causes Na diffusion to progress along the direction perpendicular to the {0001} planes. For diffusion perpendicular to the {0001} planes, Na
+
must travel by breaking tightly bonded Sb–Sb pairs and therefore overcome high energy barriers of 1.10 and 0.73 eV for the A → B and C → D pathways, respectively (
Figure
5
e). However, the energy barrier calculated parallel to the {0001} planes (i.e., the B → C pathway in
Figure
5
a,b) is relatively small (∼0.38 eV).

div.p:
Figure 5. Na trajectories near the interfaces of the (a,b) Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ and (c,d) Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couples viewed from the (a,c) [11–20] and (b,d) [0001] directions, respectively, showing the Na
+
traces used to calculate the free-energy landscapes. (e) Free-energy landscapes corresponding to the Na diffusion pathways in the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ and Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couples calculated as a function of the diffusion distance along the direction parallel to the concentration gradient (i.e., the
x
-axis). The insets in (c) are 3D views of the Sb⟨1–100⟩ and Sb⟨0001⟩ crystals, in which the Na trajectories are traced. In these insets, the direction parallel to the concentration gradients is denoted by “grad
C
”.

div.div:
By employing calculations resembling those used for the Na–Sb⟨0001⟩ diffusion couple, we also assessed energy landscapes for Na diffusion in the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple. However, in this case, the interspacing of the {0001} planes preceding the diffusion front is widened by 0.3 Å before Na
+
intercalate into the Sb crystal, as determined from the present calculations in
Figure
4
c and previous experimental work by Tian et al. described in ref [
(21)
. This widening of the {0001} interlayers would consequently reduce the energy barriers for Na diffusion along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction. Thus, to more realistically describe the energy landscapes for Na diffusion in the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple, the energy barriers for Na diffusion must be assessed by incorporating the widening of the {1100} interlayer spacing. For this purpose, a Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple was formed by widening the interlayer spacing of the Sb⟨1–100⟩ crystal by 0.3 Å (see the α → β, β → γ, and γ → δ pathways in
Figure
5
c,d).
Figure
5
e shows the energy barriers calculated for the α → β, β → γ, and γ → δ pathways in the Na–Sb⟨1–100⟩ diffusion couple, which are 0.38, 0.19, and 0.15 eV, respectively. These energy barriers are much lower than those calculated perpendicular to the {0001} planes; this explains the anisotropic Na diffusion into the Sb crystal.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In conclusion, we conducted comprehensive investigations to determine the origin of the orientation dependency of Na diffusion in the Sb crystal. In situ sodiation experiments conducted on Sb pillars with different crystallographic orientations indicated that the Na diffusion rate is significantly faster along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction than along the ⟨0001⟩ direction. Such orientation-dependent diffusion promotes anisotropic swelling of the Sb crystal, promoting crack formation associated with induction of inhomogeneous residual stresses.

First-principles calculations suggested that the different Na diffusion rate observed for the Sb pillars is due to the differing bond energies of Sb–Sb pairs forming atomic planes, with differing planar densities of the Sb crystal near the propagating interface of the sodiated Sb. Because of the high diffusion energy barrier for the Sb{0001} planes, Na diffusion is hindered along the ⟨0001⟩ direction of the Sb crystal. However, the {1100} planes provide loose and open channels. Particularly, as Na
+
begin to diffuse through the Sb{1100} planes along ⟨1–100⟩, these open channels further widen via increased interspacing of the {1100} planes, promoting rapid Na diffusion along ⟨1–100⟩. Although systematic future studies are needed, the present experimental and simulation studies show that the interatomic bond energy is an important parameter determining whether diffusion occurs isotropically or anisotropically.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Crystalline Sb pillars with diameters of ∼1.5 μm and lengths of ∼10 μm were machined from polycrystalline Sb foil (>99%) using a dual-beam FIB scanning electron microscopy (SEM) system (FIB-SEM, Quanta 3D FEG, FEI) such that their long axes were aligned along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions. (For details on how to select Sb grains with these directions and confirm the orientations of the machined pillars, see Figure S2 in the
Supporting Information
.) To machine pillars with smooth surfaces and taper angles below 2°, the beam current was gradually reduced from 300 to 10 pA during FIB milling. Potential Ga contamination resulting from FIB milling was removed by subsequent milling at a lower beam voltage (3.0 kV and 50 pA) for 2 min, followed by O
2
plasma cleaning for a further 2 min. All Sb pillars prepared from bulk Sb were then brought to a Cu FIB lift-out grid (#460-223, Ted Pella) and welded via Pt-deposition for direct-contact in situ sodiation experiments.

Crystalline Sb pillars with pure Na lumps (>99%) were used as materials for in situ sodiation experiments. To prevent oxidation of Sb and Na, the materials were handled in a glovebox filled with high-purity Ar (>99.999%) and kept oxygen-free by maintaining the O
2
and H
2
O contents below 0.5 ppm. The samples were transferred into the FIB chamber by cryotransfer (ALTO 2500, Gatan Inc.) to minimize potential O
2
and H
2
O contamination. An oxide-free Na lump surface was prepared by removing the contaminated outer surface inside the FIB chamber; this was then moved toward the crystalline Sb pillars for direct-contact in situ sodiation experiments. To analyze the Na diffusion rates along the ⟨1–100⟩ direction of the Sb crystal, the phase boundaries of the ⟨1–100⟩ Sb pillars were traced by observing the morphological changes of the pillar. However, in the case of Sb⟨0001⟩ pillars, the positions of the moving phase boundaries are obscure. Therefore, additional in situ backscattered electron (BSE) imaging was used to accurately detect the positions of the phase boundaries in the sodiated pillars (see Figure S3 in the
Supporting Information
for the BSE images of the Sb⟨0001⟩ pillar during sodiation).

div.h3: 4.3. Preparation of the Model Diffusion Couples
div.div:
To investigate the dependency of the Na diffusion kinetics on the Sb crystallographic orientation, two different Na–Sb diffusion couples were prepared by attaching a crystalline Na slab to a crystalline Sb slab such that their respective orientations were aligned along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions. However, these Na–Sb diffusion couples were structurally unstable because of the dangling bonds at the free surfaces of the Sb slabs
(27,28)
and were thus unable to accommodate the volume expansion during sodiation.
(29)
To overcome these problems, we added additional vacuum and H layers to the free-surface sides of the diffusion couples, as described in our previous studies.
(12,18,30)
Structural relaxation of the Na–Sb diffusion couples was achieved using a conjugate gradient method
(31)
until the residual forces were below 10
–3
eV/Å. During the calculations, the electronic wave functions were expanded in plane waves with an energy cutoff of 30 Ry, and only one k-point was sampled. All calculations were conducted under 3D periodic boundary conditions.

div.h3: 4.4. Analyses of Reaction Kinetics of Sb Crystal Sodiation
div.div:
Car–Parrinello molecular dynamics (CPMD) simulations
(32)
were conducted using the model diffusion couples to describe spontaneous Na diffusion in the Sb crystal and its orientation dependency. Of various ensembles usable in CPMD, the NPT ensemble enables description of the increase in the interlayer spacing of the Sb{1100} planes and therefore provides the most reliable information concerning Sb crystal sodiation. However, the NPT ensemble involves a high computational cost, hindering sodiation simulation for the Sb crystal. To decrease the computational cost and effectively investigate the structural evolution of the Na–Sb diffusion couples, the spontaneous sodiation of the Sb crystal was initially calculated using the NPT ensemble for 6 ps followed by the NVT ensemble for 7 ps. Na diffusion in the Na–Sb diffusion couples was accelerated at an elevated temperature of 500 K, controlled using a Nosè-Hoover thermostat.
(33)
The classical equations of motion were solved by employing the Verlet algorithm for 12.0 ps using a time step of 0.12 fs. Interactions between the valence electrons and ionic cores are described by norm-conserving pseudopotentials.
(34,35)
The total energy calculations of the model structures are based on the generalized gradient approximation functional with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof
(36)
correction as implemented in the Quantum Espresso package.
(33)

The orientation-dependent diffusion kinetics of Na in the Sb crystal were further analyzed by calculating the energy landscape of the Na diffusion pathways using the nudged elastic band (NEB) method.
(37)
This was achieved by intentionally selecting the initial Na diffusion pathway and adjusting it so that the Na
+
could travel along the pathway that required the least energy. For this purpose, two different Sb crystals were prepared by aligning their orientations along the ⟨1–100⟩ and ⟨0001⟩ directions. Each Sb crystal was formed by stacking four layers of (1–100) and (0001) planes of Sb. To overcome problems associated with the volume expansion and dangling bonds of the Sb crystal, additional vacuum and H layers were added to the free-surface sides of the Sb crystal, as described in our previous work.
(12,18,30)
A Na atom was then placed in the Sb crystal such that the initial Na diffusion pathway for NEB calculations connected the interstitial Na sites in the Sb crystal. The initial diffusion pathway was then adjusted so that the Na
+
could travel along the pathway requiring the least energy. The diffusion pathways were described using a discrete sequence of nine atomic configurations. The geometry and energy of each atomic configuration were subsequently relaxed until the largest force orthogonal to the path was below 0.05 eV/Å. All the H layers and the bottom two planes of the Sb crystals were fixed for all calculations.

Na-ion batteries have been proposed as candidates for replacing Li-ion batteries. The authors examine the viability of Na-ion anode materials based on Na alloys or hard carbons in terms of volumetric energy d. Due to the bigger size of the Na atom compared to the Li atom, Na alloys would lead to anode materials with about half the volumetric energy d. of their Li analogs. Volumetric energy densities obtainable with sodiated hard carbons would also be significantly less than those obtainable with lithiated graphite. These findings highlight the need of novel ideas for Na-ion anodes.

Pure micrometric antimony can be successfully used as neg. electrode material in Na-ion batteries, sustaining a capacity close to 600 mAh g-1 at a high rate with a Coulombic efficiency of 99 over 160 cycles, an extremely high capacity compared to any other compd. tested against both Li and Na. The reaction mechanism with Na does not simply go through the alloying mechanism obsd. for Li where the intermediate species are those expected from the phase diagram. In the case of Na, the intermediate phases are mostly amorphous and could not be precisely identified. Surprisingly, it is evidenced that a competition takes place at the end of the discharge of the Sb/Na cell between the formation of the hexagonal and the cubic polymorphs of Na3Sb, the last being described in the literature as unstable at atm. pressure and only synthesized under high pressure (1-9 GPa). In addn., fluoroethylene carbonate added to the electrolyte combined with an appropriate electrode formulation based on CM-cellulose, carbon black, and vapor ground carbon fibers seems to be determinant in the excellent performances of this material.

Group-VA crystals have higher theor. energy capacities than graphite as anode materials for Li/Na ion batteries. However, their bulks suffer from severe vol. expansion and structural breakdown during lithiation or sodiation process, leading to abrupt drop of battery cycle performance. Our exptl. and computational results reveal that 2-dimensional (2D) group-VA crystals can preserve layered configuration without obvious structure damage. Here, we study the mechanism of 2D P, As, and Sb high-capacity anodes for fast-charging Li/Na ion batteries by calcd. binding and diffusion properties of Li/Na on group-VA monolayers. Promisingly, group-VA monolayers can give rise to greater charge/discharge capability than their corresponding parent bulk materials. This is mainly because these 2D group-VA materials with c axis free expansion hold appropriate interaction with Li/Na atoms and enjoy esp. lower energy barriers than their bulks. The energy barriers calcns. of monolayers under mech. stretching indicate that the structural roughness also plays a role in hard ion mobility in bulk structure besides space constraint. We also evaluate the performance of group-VA monolayers by calcg. their d. of states and open circuit voltages. These results provide conclusive evidence showing that 2D group-VA materials are promising anodes for Li/Na ion batteries.

Accurate description of the mech. behavior of cryst. Na alloys is essential in establishing their electrochem. performance as well as their viability as anodes in Na-ion batteries. Using first principles simulations, we have investigated the intrinsic elastic properties of cryst. Na-M (M = Sn, Pb, Si and Ge) phases obsd. during Na intercalation. We have obtained the complete set of concn.-dependent anisotropic elastic consts. as well as the av. macroscopic elastic moduli of polycryst. structures. We find that sodiation of pure M phases leads to a remarkable elastic softening that results in up to 75% deterioration of the elastic moduli. Our anal. of the electronic charge distribution demonstrates that the elastic softening during sodiation originates from a transition to weaker ionic interat. bonding. Our results highlight the significance of the concn. dependence of the elastic moduli for the anal. of deformation behavior of Na alloy anodes of Na-ion batteries during sodiation and desodiation.

Na-ion batteries have recently attracted significant attention as an alternative to Li-ion batteries because Na sources do not present the geopolitical issues that Li sources might. Although recent reports on cathode materials for Na-ion batteries demonstrated performances comparable to their Li-ion counterparts, the major scientific challenge for a competitive Na-ion battery technol. is to develop viable anode materials. A hybrid material made out of a few phosphorene layers sandwiched between graphene layers shows a specific capacity of 2 440 mA h g-1 (calcd. using the mass of P only) at a c.d. of 0.05 A g-1 and an 83% capacity retention after 100 cycles while operating between 0 and 1.5 V. Using in situ TEM and ex situ x-ray diffraction techniques, the authors explain the large capacity of the anode through a dual mechanism of intercalation of Na ions along the x axis of the phosphorene layers followed by the formation of a Na3P alloy. The presence of graphene layers in the hybrid material works as a mech. backbone and an elec. highway, ensuring that a suitable elastic buffer space accommodates the anisotropic expansion of phosphorene layers along the y and z axial directions for stable cycling operation.

Na-ion batteries offer an attractive option for low cost grid scale storage due to the abundance of Na. Sn is touted as a high capacity anode for Na-ion batteries with a high theor. capacity of 847 mA-h/g, but it has several limitations such as large vol. expansion with cycling, slow kinetics, and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation. An anode consisting of a Sn thin film deposited on a hierarchical wood fiber substrate simultaneously addresses all the challenges assocd. with Sn anodes. The soft nature of wood fibers effectively releases the mech. stresses assocd. with the sodiation process, and the mesoporous structure functions as an electrolyte reservoir that allows for ion transport through the outer and inner surface of the fiber. These properties are confirmed exptl. and computationally. A stable cycling performance of 400 cycles with an initial capacity of 339 mA-h/g is demonstrated; a significant improvement over other reported Sn nanostructures. The soft and mesoporous wood fiber substrate can be used as a new platform for low cost Na-ion batteries.

Phosphorene, an emerging two-dimensional material, has received considerable attention due to its layer-controlled direct bandgap, high carrier mobility, neg. Poisson's ratio and unique in-plane anisotropy. As cousins of phosphorene, 2D group-VA arsenene, antimonene and bismuthene have also garnered tremendous interest due to their intriguing structures and fascinating electronic properties. 2D group-VA family members are opening up brand-new opportunities for their multifunctional applications encompassing electronics, optoelectronics, topol. spintronics, thermoelecs., sensors, Li- or Na-batteries. In this review, we extensively explore the latest theor. and exptl. progress made in the fundamental properties, fabrications and applications of 2D group-VA materials, and offer perspectives and challenges for the future of this emerging field.

Phosphorus represents a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries owing to its extremely high theor. capacity. Recent in situ transmission electron microscopy studies evidenced anisotropic swelling in sodiated black phosphorus, which may find an origin from the two intrinsic anisotropic properties inherent to the layered structure of black phosphorus: sodium diffusional directionality and insertion strain anisotropy. To understand the morphol. evolution and stress generation in sodiated black phosphorus, we develop a chemo-mech. model by incorporating the intrinsic anisotropic properties into the large elasto-plastic deformation. Our modeling results reveal that the apparent morphol. evolution in sodiated black phosphorus is critically controlled by the coupled effect of the two intrinsic anisotropic properties. In particular, sodium diffusional directionality generates sharp interphases along the [010] and [001] directions, which constrain anisotropic development of the insertion strain. The coupled effect renders distinctive stress-generation and fracture mechanisms when sodiation starts from different crystal facets. In addn. to providing a powerful modeling framework for sodiation and lithiation of layered structures, our findings shed significant light on the sodiation-induced chemo-mech. degrdn. of black phosphorus as a promising anode for the next-generation sodium ion batteries.

Black phosphorus (BP) has drawn growing attention as the anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of its high theor. lithium storage capacity. However, its electrochem. processes and fundamental failure mechanisms have not been completely understood due to the lack of direct evidence. Here, we report the direct visualization of the electrochem. lithiation/delithiation behavior of the BP anode in nano-LIBs using the in situ transmission electron microscopy technique. Upon lithiation, the BP anode is found to undergo obvious anisotropic size expansion and phase change from orthorhombic BP to amorphous LixPy compds. Unexpectedly, the BP anode pulverizes suddenly during discharging, resulting in irreversibility of the lithiated product and thus poor electrochem. cycling performance. This finding discloses that the failure mechanism of the BP anode is mainly correlated with the delithiation process rather than the lithiation one, which subverts the commonly accepted understanding. The new mechanism insights would serve to provide viable solns. for eliminating rapid capacity fading that plagues the bulk BP LIBs.

As opposed to the common understanding that diffusion into a cubic-structured single crystal is independent of its crystalline orientation, the diffusion of Li to crystalline Si (c-Si) is anisotropic, which acts as the major cause for the fracture of Si anodes in Li-ion batteries. Here, by conducting comprehensive/multi-scale simulation studies based on molecular dynamics and density functional theory, we elucidate how and why Li diffusion in c-Si is anisotropic. We found that Li ions diffuse to c-Si by following a particular atomic-scale space corresponding to the lowest value of the valence orbital in c-Si, causing Li ions to take a tortuous diffusion pathway. The degree of the tortuosity of the pathway differs depending on the crystallographic orientation of Si, and it acts as the major cause for anisotropic lithiation. We also develop a structural parameter that can quantitatively evaluate the orientation dependency of the lithiation of c-Si.

Silicon is one of the most attractive anode materials for use in Li-ion batteries due to its ∼10 times higher specific capacity than existing graphite anodes. However, up to 400% vol. expansion during reaction with Li causes particle pulverization and fracture, which results in rapid capacity fading. Although Si nanomaterials showed improvements in electrochem. performance, there is limited understanding of how vol. expansion takes place. Here, the authors study the shape and vol. changes of cryst. Si nanopillars with different orientations upon 1st lithiation and discover anomalous behavior. Upon lithiation, the initially circular cross sections of nanopillars with 〈100〉, and 〈110〉, and 〈111〉 axial orientations expand into cross, ellipse, and hexagonal shapes, resp. The authors explain this by identifying a high-speed lithium ion diffusion channel along the 〈110〉 direction, which causes preferential vol. expansion along this direction. Surprisingly, the 〈111〉 and 〈100〉 nanopillars shrink in height after partial lithiation, while 〈110〉 nanopillars increase in height. The length contraction probably is due to a collapse of the {111} planes early in the lithiation process. These results give new insight into the Si vol. change process and could help in designing better battery anodes.

In lithium-ion batteries, the electrochem. reaction between the electrodes and lithium is a crit. process that controls the capacity, cyclability and reliability of the battery. Despite intensive study, the atomistic mechanism of the electrochem. reactions occurring in these solid-state electrodes remains unclear. Here, we show that in situ TEM can be used to study the dynamic lithiation process of single-crystal silicon with at. resoln. We observe a sharp interface (∼1 nm thick) between the cryst. silicon and an amorphous LixSi alloy. The lithiation kinetics are controlled by the migration of the interface, which occurs through a ledge mechanism involving the lateral movement of ledges on the close-packed {111} at. planes. Such ledge flow processes produce the amorphous LixSi alloy through layer-by-layer peeling of the {111} at. facets, resulting in the orientation-dependent mobility of the interfaces.

We employed an in situ electrochem. cell in the transmission electron microscope (TEM) together with ex situ time-of-flight, secondary-ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) depth profiling, and FIB-helium ion scanning microscope (HIM) imaging to detail the structural and compositional changes assocd. with Na/Na+ charging/discharging of 50 and 100 nm thin films of Sb. TOF-SIMS on a partially sodiated 100 nm Sb film gives a Na signal that progressively decreases toward the current collector, indicating that sodiation does not proceed uniformly. This heterogeneity will lead to local volumetric expansion gradients that would in turn serve as a major source of intrinsic stress in the microstructure. In situ TEM shows time-dependent buckling and localized sepn. of the sodiated films from their TiN-Ge nanowire support, which is a mechanism of stress-relaxation. Localized horizontal fracture does not occur directly at the interface, but rather at a short distance away within the bulk of the Sb. HIM images of FIB cross sections taken from sodiated half-cells, elec. disconnected, and aged at room temp., demonstrate nonuniform film swelling and the onset of analogous through-bulk sepn. TOF-SIMS highlights time-dependent segregation of Na within the structure, both to the film-current collector interface and to the film surface where a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) exists, agreeing with the electrochem. impedance results that show time-dependent increase of the films' charge transfer resistance. We propose that Na segregation serves as a secondary source of stress relief, which occurs over somewhat longer time scales.

Recent independent expts. demonstrated that the lithiation-induced vol. expansion in silicon nanowires, nanopillars, and microslabs is highly anisotropic, with predominant expansion along the 〈110〉 direction but negligibly small expansion along the 〈111〉 direction. The origin of such anisotropic behavior remains elusive. Here, the authors develop a chemomech. model to study the phase evolution and morphol. changes in lithiated silicon nanowires. The model couples the diffusive reaction of lithium with the lithiation-induced elasto-plastic deformation. The apparent anisotropic swelling is critically controlled by the orientation-dependent mobility of the core-shell interface, i.e., the lithiation reaction rate at the atomically sharp phase boundary between the cryst. core and the amorphous shell. The results also underscore the importance of structural relaxation by plastic flow behind the moving phase boundary, which is essential to quant. prediction of the exptl. obsd. morphologies of lithiated silicon nanowires. The study sheds light on the lithiation-mediated failure in nanowire-based electrodes, and the modeling framework provides a basis for simulating the morphol. evolution, stress generation, and fracture in high-capacity electrodes for the next-generation lithium-ion batteries.

To realize Si as an anode material in com. Li-ion batteries it is important to understand the mixing mechanism of Li and Si, and stress evolution during lithiation in Si neg. electrode of Li-ion batteries. Expts. mainly provide the diffusivity of Li in Si as an averaged property, neglecting information regarding diffusivity of Si. However, if Si can diffuse as fast as Li, the stress generated during Li diffusion can be decreased. The authors, therefore, studied the diffusivity of Li as well as Si atoms in the Si-anode of Li-ion battery using an ab initio mol. dynamics-based methodol. The electrochem. insertion of Li into cryst. Si prompts a cryst.-to-amorphous phase transition. The authors considered this situation and thus examd. the diffusion kinetics of Li and Si atoms in both cryst. and amorphous Si. Li diffuses faster in amorphous Si as compared to cryst. Si, while Si remains relatively immobile in both cases and generates stresses during lithiation. To further understand the mixing mechanism and to relate the structure with electrochem. mixing, the authors analyzed the evolution of the structure during lithiation and studied the mechanism of breaking of Si-Si network by Li. Li atoms break the Si rings and chains and create ephemeral structures such as stars and boomerangs, which eventually transform to Si-Si dumbbells and isolated Si atoms in the LiSi phase. The results are in agreement with exptl. data and provide insights into the mixing mechanism of Li and Si in Si anodes of Li-ion batteries.

We present a simple procedure to generate first-principles norm-conserving pseudopotentials, which are designed to be smooth and therefore save computational resources when used with a plane-wave basis. We found that these pseudopotentials are extremely efficient for the cases where the plane-wave expansion has a slow convergence, in particular, for systems contg. first-row elements, transition metals, and rare earth elements. The wide applicability of the pseudopotentials are exemplified with plane-wave calcns. for copper, zinc blende, diamond, α-quartz, rutile, and cerium.

We present pseudopotential coeffs. for the first two rows of the Periodic Table. The pseudopotential is of an analytic form that gives optimal efficiency in numerical calculations using plane waves as a basis set. At most, even coeffs. are necessary to specify its analytic form. It is separable and has optimal decay properties in both real and Fourier space. Because of this property, the application of the nonlocal part of the pseudopotential to a wave function can be done efficiently on a grid in real space. Real space integration is much faster for large systems than ordinary multiplication in Fourier space, since it shows only quadratic scaling with respect to the size of the system. We systematically verify the high accuracy of these pseudopotentials by extensive at. and mol. test calcns.

A modification of the nudged elastic band method for finding min. energy paths is presented. One of the images is made to climb up along the elastic band to converge rigorously on the highest saddle point. Also, variable spring consts. are used to increase the d. of images near the top of the energy barrier to get an improved est. of the reaction coordinate near the saddle point. Applications to CH4 dissociative adsorption on Ir(111) and H2 on Si(100) using plane wave based d. functional theory are presented.

Na-ion batteries have been proposed as candidates for replacing Li-ion batteries. The authors examine the viability of Na-ion anode materials based on Na alloys or hard carbons in terms of volumetric energy d. Due to the bigger size of the Na atom compared to the Li atom, Na alloys would lead to anode materials with about half the volumetric energy d. of their Li analogs. Volumetric energy densities obtainable with sodiated hard carbons would also be significantly less than those obtainable with lithiated graphite. These findings highlight the need of novel ideas for Na-ion anodes.

Pure micrometric antimony can be successfully used as neg. electrode material in Na-ion batteries, sustaining a capacity close to 600 mAh g-1 at a high rate with a Coulombic efficiency of 99 over 160 cycles, an extremely high capacity compared to any other compd. tested against both Li and Na. The reaction mechanism with Na does not simply go through the alloying mechanism obsd. for Li where the intermediate species are those expected from the phase diagram. In the case of Na, the intermediate phases are mostly amorphous and could not be precisely identified. Surprisingly, it is evidenced that a competition takes place at the end of the discharge of the Sb/Na cell between the formation of the hexagonal and the cubic polymorphs of Na3Sb, the last being described in the literature as unstable at atm. pressure and only synthesized under high pressure (1-9 GPa). In addn., fluoroethylene carbonate added to the electrolyte combined with an appropriate electrode formulation based on CM-cellulose, carbon black, and vapor ground carbon fibers seems to be determinant in the excellent performances of this material.

Group-VA crystals have higher theor. energy capacities than graphite as anode materials for Li/Na ion batteries. However, their bulks suffer from severe vol. expansion and structural breakdown during lithiation or sodiation process, leading to abrupt drop of battery cycle performance. Our exptl. and computational results reveal that 2-dimensional (2D) group-VA crystals can preserve layered configuration without obvious structure damage. Here, we study the mechanism of 2D P, As, and Sb high-capacity anodes for fast-charging Li/Na ion batteries by calcd. binding and diffusion properties of Li/Na on group-VA monolayers. Promisingly, group-VA monolayers can give rise to greater charge/discharge capability than their corresponding parent bulk materials. This is mainly because these 2D group-VA materials with c axis free expansion hold appropriate interaction with Li/Na atoms and enjoy esp. lower energy barriers than their bulks. The energy barriers calcns. of monolayers under mech. stretching indicate that the structural roughness also plays a role in hard ion mobility in bulk structure besides space constraint. We also evaluate the performance of group-VA monolayers by calcg. their d. of states and open circuit voltages. These results provide conclusive evidence showing that 2D group-VA materials are promising anodes for Li/Na ion batteries.

Accurate description of the mech. behavior of cryst. Na alloys is essential in establishing their electrochem. performance as well as their viability as anodes in Na-ion batteries. Using first principles simulations, we have investigated the intrinsic elastic properties of cryst. Na-M (M = Sn, Pb, Si and Ge) phases obsd. during Na intercalation. We have obtained the complete set of concn.-dependent anisotropic elastic consts. as well as the av. macroscopic elastic moduli of polycryst. structures. We find that sodiation of pure M phases leads to a remarkable elastic softening that results in up to 75% deterioration of the elastic moduli. Our anal. of the electronic charge distribution demonstrates that the elastic softening during sodiation originates from a transition to weaker ionic interat. bonding. Our results highlight the significance of the concn. dependence of the elastic moduli for the anal. of deformation behavior of Na alloy anodes of Na-ion batteries during sodiation and desodiation.

Na-ion batteries have recently attracted significant attention as an alternative to Li-ion batteries because Na sources do not present the geopolitical issues that Li sources might. Although recent reports on cathode materials for Na-ion batteries demonstrated performances comparable to their Li-ion counterparts, the major scientific challenge for a competitive Na-ion battery technol. is to develop viable anode materials. A hybrid material made out of a few phosphorene layers sandwiched between graphene layers shows a specific capacity of 2 440 mA h g-1 (calcd. using the mass of P only) at a c.d. of 0.05 A g-1 and an 83% capacity retention after 100 cycles while operating between 0 and 1.5 V. Using in situ TEM and ex situ x-ray diffraction techniques, the authors explain the large capacity of the anode through a dual mechanism of intercalation of Na ions along the x axis of the phosphorene layers followed by the formation of a Na3P alloy. The presence of graphene layers in the hybrid material works as a mech. backbone and an elec. highway, ensuring that a suitable elastic buffer space accommodates the anisotropic expansion of phosphorene layers along the y and z axial directions for stable cycling operation.

Na-ion batteries offer an attractive option for low cost grid scale storage due to the abundance of Na. Sn is touted as a high capacity anode for Na-ion batteries with a high theor. capacity of 847 mA-h/g, but it has several limitations such as large vol. expansion with cycling, slow kinetics, and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation. An anode consisting of a Sn thin film deposited on a hierarchical wood fiber substrate simultaneously addresses all the challenges assocd. with Sn anodes. The soft nature of wood fibers effectively releases the mech. stresses assocd. with the sodiation process, and the mesoporous structure functions as an electrolyte reservoir that allows for ion transport through the outer and inner surface of the fiber. These properties are confirmed exptl. and computationally. A stable cycling performance of 400 cycles with an initial capacity of 339 mA-h/g is demonstrated; a significant improvement over other reported Sn nanostructures. The soft and mesoporous wood fiber substrate can be used as a new platform for low cost Na-ion batteries.

Phosphorene, an emerging two-dimensional material, has received considerable attention due to its layer-controlled direct bandgap, high carrier mobility, neg. Poisson's ratio and unique in-plane anisotropy. As cousins of phosphorene, 2D group-VA arsenene, antimonene and bismuthene have also garnered tremendous interest due to their intriguing structures and fascinating electronic properties. 2D group-VA family members are opening up brand-new opportunities for their multifunctional applications encompassing electronics, optoelectronics, topol. spintronics, thermoelecs., sensors, Li- or Na-batteries. In this review, we extensively explore the latest theor. and exptl. progress made in the fundamental properties, fabrications and applications of 2D group-VA materials, and offer perspectives and challenges for the future of this emerging field.

Phosphorus represents a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries owing to its extremely high theor. capacity. Recent in situ transmission electron microscopy studies evidenced anisotropic swelling in sodiated black phosphorus, which may find an origin from the two intrinsic anisotropic properties inherent to the layered structure of black phosphorus: sodium diffusional directionality and insertion strain anisotropy. To understand the morphol. evolution and stress generation in sodiated black phosphorus, we develop a chemo-mech. model by incorporating the intrinsic anisotropic properties into the large elasto-plastic deformation. Our modeling results reveal that the apparent morphol. evolution in sodiated black phosphorus is critically controlled by the coupled effect of the two intrinsic anisotropic properties. In particular, sodium diffusional directionality generates sharp interphases along the [010] and [001] directions, which constrain anisotropic development of the insertion strain. The coupled effect renders distinctive stress-generation and fracture mechanisms when sodiation starts from different crystal facets. In addn. to providing a powerful modeling framework for sodiation and lithiation of layered structures, our findings shed significant light on the sodiation-induced chemo-mech. degrdn. of black phosphorus as a promising anode for the next-generation sodium ion batteries.

Black phosphorus (BP) has drawn growing attention as the anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of its high theor. lithium storage capacity. However, its electrochem. processes and fundamental failure mechanisms have not been completely understood due to the lack of direct evidence. Here, we report the direct visualization of the electrochem. lithiation/delithiation behavior of the BP anode in nano-LIBs using the in situ transmission electron microscopy technique. Upon lithiation, the BP anode is found to undergo obvious anisotropic size expansion and phase change from orthorhombic BP to amorphous LixPy compds. Unexpectedly, the BP anode pulverizes suddenly during discharging, resulting in irreversibility of the lithiated product and thus poor electrochem. cycling performance. This finding discloses that the failure mechanism of the BP anode is mainly correlated with the delithiation process rather than the lithiation one, which subverts the commonly accepted understanding. The new mechanism insights would serve to provide viable solns. for eliminating rapid capacity fading that plagues the bulk BP LIBs.

As opposed to the common understanding that diffusion into a cubic-structured single crystal is independent of its crystalline orientation, the diffusion of Li to crystalline Si (c-Si) is anisotropic, which acts as the major cause for the fracture of Si anodes in Li-ion batteries. Here, by conducting comprehensive/multi-scale simulation studies based on molecular dynamics and density functional theory, we elucidate how and why Li diffusion in c-Si is anisotropic. We found that Li ions diffuse to c-Si by following a particular atomic-scale space corresponding to the lowest value of the valence orbital in c-Si, causing Li ions to take a tortuous diffusion pathway. The degree of the tortuosity of the pathway differs depending on the crystallographic orientation of Si, and it acts as the major cause for anisotropic lithiation. We also develop a structural parameter that can quantitatively evaluate the orientation dependency of the lithiation of c-Si.

Silicon is one of the most attractive anode materials for use in Li-ion batteries due to its ∼10 times higher specific capacity than existing graphite anodes. However, up to 400% vol. expansion during reaction with Li causes particle pulverization and fracture, which results in rapid capacity fading. Although Si nanomaterials showed improvements in electrochem. performance, there is limited understanding of how vol. expansion takes place. Here, the authors study the shape and vol. changes of cryst. Si nanopillars with different orientations upon 1st lithiation and discover anomalous behavior. Upon lithiation, the initially circular cross sections of nanopillars with 〈100〉, and 〈110〉, and 〈111〉 axial orientations expand into cross, ellipse, and hexagonal shapes, resp. The authors explain this by identifying a high-speed lithium ion diffusion channel along the 〈110〉 direction, which causes preferential vol. expansion along this direction. Surprisingly, the 〈111〉 and 〈100〉 nanopillars shrink in height after partial lithiation, while 〈110〉 nanopillars increase in height. The length contraction probably is due to a collapse of the {111} planes early in the lithiation process. These results give new insight into the Si vol. change process and could help in designing better battery anodes.

We employed an in situ electrochem. cell in the transmission electron microscope (TEM) together with ex situ time-of-flight, secondary-ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) depth profiling, and FIB-helium ion scanning microscope (HIM) imaging to detail the structural and compositional changes assocd. with Na/Na+ charging/discharging of 50 and 100 nm thin films of Sb. TOF-SIMS on a partially sodiated 100 nm Sb film gives a Na signal that progressively decreases toward the current collector, indicating that sodiation does not proceed uniformly. This heterogeneity will lead to local volumetric expansion gradients that would in turn serve as a major source of intrinsic stress in the microstructure. In situ TEM shows time-dependent buckling and localized sepn. of the sodiated films from their TiN-Ge nanowire support, which is a mechanism of stress-relaxation. Localized horizontal fracture does not occur directly at the interface, but rather at a short distance away within the bulk of the Sb. HIM images of FIB cross sections taken from sodiated half-cells, elec. disconnected, and aged at room temp., demonstrate nonuniform film swelling and the onset of analogous through-bulk sepn. TOF-SIMS highlights time-dependent segregation of Na within the structure, both to the film-current collector interface and to the film surface where a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) exists, agreeing with the electrochem. impedance results that show time-dependent increase of the films' charge transfer resistance. We propose that Na segregation serves as a secondary source of stress relief, which occurs over somewhat longer time scales.

Recent independent expts. demonstrated that the lithiation-induced vol. expansion in silicon nanowires, nanopillars, and microslabs is highly anisotropic, with predominant expansion along the 〈110〉 direction but negligibly small expansion along the 〈111〉 direction. The origin of such anisotropic behavior remains elusive. Here, the authors develop a chemomech. model to study the phase evolution and morphol. changes in lithiated silicon nanowires. The model couples the diffusive reaction of lithium with the lithiation-induced elasto-plastic deformation. The apparent anisotropic swelling is critically controlled by the orientation-dependent mobility of the core-shell interface, i.e., the lithiation reaction rate at the atomically sharp phase boundary between the cryst. core and the amorphous shell. The results also underscore the importance of structural relaxation by plastic flow behind the moving phase boundary, which is essential to quant. prediction of the exptl. obsd. morphologies of lithiated silicon nanowires. The study sheds light on the lithiation-mediated failure in nanowire-based electrodes, and the modeling framework provides a basis for simulating the morphol. evolution, stress generation, and fracture in high-capacity electrodes for the next-generation lithium-ion batteries.

1530-6984
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
To realize Si as an anode material in com. Li-ion batteries it is important to understand the mixing mechanism of Li and Si, and stress evolution during lithiation in Si neg. electrode of Li-ion batteries. Expts. mainly provide the diffusivity of Li in Si as an averaged property, neglecting information regarding diffusivity of Si. However, if Si can diffuse as fast as Li, the stress generated during Li diffusion can be decreased. The authors, therefore, studied the diffusivity of Li as well as Si atoms in the Si-anode of Li-ion battery using an ab initio mol. dynamics-based methodol. The electrochem. insertion of Li into cryst. Si prompts a cryst.-to-amorphous phase transition. The authors considered this situation and thus examd. the diffusion kinetics of Li and Si atoms in both cryst. and amorphous Si. Li diffuses faster in amorphous Si as compared to cryst. Si, while Si remains relatively immobile in both cases and generates stresses during lithiation. To further understand the mixing mechanism and to relate the structure with electrochem. mixing, the authors analyzed the evolution of the structure during lithiation and studied the mechanism of breaking of Si-Si network by Li. Li atoms break the Si rings and chains and create ephemeral structures such as stars and boomerangs, which eventually transform to Si-Si dumbbells and isolated Si atoms in the LiSi phase. The results are in agreement with exptl. data and provide insights into the mixing mechanism of Li and Si in Si anodes of Li-ion batteries.

The Cerjan-Miller eigenvector-following method is highly successful in finding saddle points for a variety of clusters whose potential energy surfaces are well described using simple anal. pair potentials. Examples are given for Ar clusters, including Ar33 and Ar55, KCl clusters and clusters of ions held in an "ion trap". The method reveals a no. of important patterns and opens the way to a more detailed understanding of the relation between energetics, reactivity, and potential energy surfaces for these and other systems.

A unified scheme is given that, by combining mol. dynamics and d.-functional theory, profoundly extends the range of both concepts. This approach extends mol. dynamics beyond the usual pair-potential approxn., thereby making possible the simulation of both covalently bonded and metallic systems. In addn., it permits the application of d.-functional theory to much larger systems than previously feasible. The new technique is demonstrated by the calcn. of some static and dynamic properties of cryst. Si within a self-consistent pseudopotential framework.

We present a simple procedure to generate first-principles norm-conserving pseudopotentials, which are designed to be smooth and therefore save computational resources when used with a plane-wave basis. We found that these pseudopotentials are extremely efficient for the cases where the plane-wave expansion has a slow convergence, in particular, for systems contg. first-row elements, transition metals, and rare earth elements. The wide applicability of the pseudopotentials are exemplified with plane-wave calcns. for copper, zinc blende, diamond, α-quartz, rutile, and cerium.

We present pseudopotential coeffs. for the first two rows of the Periodic Table. The pseudopotential is of an analytic form that gives optimal efficiency in numerical calculations using plane waves as a basis set. At most, even coeffs. are necessary to specify its analytic form. It is separable and has optimal decay properties in both real and Fourier space. Because of this property, the application of the nonlocal part of the pseudopotential to a wave function can be done efficiently on a grid in real space. Real space integration is much faster for large systems than ordinary multiplication in Fourier space, since it shows only quadratic scaling with respect to the size of the system. We systematically verify the high accuracy of these pseudopotentials by extensive at. and mol. test calcns.

Pseudopotential parameter sets for the elements from H to Kr using the relativistic, norm-conserving, separable, dual-space Gaussian-type pseudopotentials of Goedecker, Teter, and Hutter (GTH) are presented as optimized for the gradient-cor. exchange-correlation functionals of Becke, Lee, Yang, and Parr (BLYP), Becke and Perdew (BP), and Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE). The accuracy and reliability of the GTH pseudopotentials is shown by calcns. for a series of small mols.

A modification of the nudged elastic band method for finding min. energy paths is presented. One of the images is made to climb up along the elastic band to converge rigorously on the highest saddle point. Also, variable spring consts. are used to increase the d. of images near the top of the energy barrier to get an improved est. of the reaction coordinate near the saddle point. Applications to CH4 dissociative adsorption on Ir(111) and H2 on Si(100) using plane wave based d. functional theory are presented.
